message.content: This question requires some basic knowledge about the action of raking and its effects on objects. When something is raked over firmly, it is likely to lose a portion of its contents or surface. Option (A) is incorrect because losing a pebble implies that the pebble was on top of the thing, rather than being part of the thing itself. Option (B) is incorrect because being built up implies adding material, which is not related to raking. Option (D) is also incorrect because growing larger is not a result of raking.

This question requires interpreting the phrase "firmly raked over" and its effects on an object. When something is "raked over," it suggests that there is a motion or action of removing or redistributing items. Option (C) is the correct answer because if something is raked over, it may lose a portion of its contents due to the action of redistributing or removing them. Options (A), (B), and (D) do not directly relate to the concept of something being raked over.

This question requires an understanding of the action of raking over something. When something is firmly raked over, it means that something is being removed or cleared away. Therefore, the thing may lose a portion. Option (A) is incorrect because losing a pebble is too specific and may not always be the case. Option (B) is incorrect because being built up is the opposite of what happens when something is raked over. Option (D) is incorrect because growing larger is unrelated to the action of raking over something.

To answer this question, we need to understand the meaning of the phrase "firmly raked over." The word "rake" typically refers to a tool used to gather leaves or debris. In this context, "firmly raked over" suggests that something is being combed or smoothed out with a rake. 

When something is firmly raked over, it is likely to lose a portion. This is because the act of raking over an object would remove any loose or excess material, such as pebbles or dirt. Option (A) correctly identifies this outcome.

Options (B) and (D) are unlikely as they suggest that the object will be built up or grow larger, which is contrary to what is implied by the phrase "firmly raked over." Option (C) correctly captures the idea that a portion of the object will be lost or removed during the process.
